Status: Inpatient
Date/Time: [**2194-1-22**] at 14:30
Test: Portable TTE (Complete)
Doppler: Full Doppler and color Doppler
Contrast: None
Technical Quality: Adequate


INTERPRETATION:

Findings:

This study was compared to the prior study of [**2194-1-8**].


LEFT ATRIUM: Mild LA enlargement.

RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: Normal RA size. Normal interatrial septum. No
ASD by 2D or color Doppler.

LEFT VENTRICLE: Normal LV wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global
systolic function (LVEF >55%). No resting LVOT gradient. No VSD.

RIGHT VENTRICLE: Normal RV chamber size and free wall motion.

AORTA: Normal aortic diameter at the sinus level. Mildly dilated ascending
aorta. No 2D or Doppler evidence of distal arch coarctation.

AORTIC VALVE: Mildly thickened aortic valve leaflets (3). No AS. Trace AR.

MITRAL VALVE: Mildly thickened mitral valve leaflets. Trivial MR. LV inflow
pattern c/w impaired relaxation.

TRICUSPID VALVE: Normal tricuspid valve leaflets with trivial TR.
Indeterminate PA systolic pressure.

PULMONIC VALVE/PULMONARY ARTERY: No PS.

PERICARDIUM: No pericardial effusion.

Conclusions:
The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or
color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and
regional/global systolic function are normal (LVEF >55%) There is no
ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion
are normal. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets
(3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace aortic
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Trivial
mitral regurgitation is seen. The left ventricular inflow pattern suggests
impaired relaxation. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be
determined. There is no pericardial effusion.

Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2194-1-8**], no change.

[**2194-1-27**] 7:40 AM
 PICC LINE PLACMENT SCH                                          Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14610**]
 Reason: Please place IR-guided PICC for abx
 Admitting Diagnosis: HYPOTENSION
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 20
 ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
 * [**Numeric Identifier 273**] PICC W/O [**Numeric Identifier 352**] FLUORO GUID PLCT/REPLCT/REMOVE   *
 * [**Numeric Identifier 9**] US GUID FOR VAS. ACCESS                                                *
 ****************************************************************************
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  [**Age over 90 **] year old woman with anasarca, hypotension, receiving abx
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Please place IR-guided PICC for abx
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  [**Age over 90 **]-year-old female receiving antibiotics.

 The procedure was explained to the patient.  A preprocedural timeout was
 performed.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 353**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) **] performed the procedure.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **],
 the attending radiologist, was present and supervising.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copy ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, attempts were
 made to advance the guidewire into the SVC.  The guidewire would not advance
 past the axillary vein and therefore a peel-away sheath was placed and a
 venogram performed demonstrating a short, tight stenosis at the right
 axillary/ subclavian vein junction.

 The area of stenosis was traversed under fluoroscopic guidance using a 0.018
 Glidewire.  A repeat venogram demonstrated a small amount of extravasated
 extraluminal contrast; however, the Glidewire was subsequently successfully
 navigated into the SVC.  A single lumen PICC line measuring 43 cm in length
 was then placed through the peel-away sheath with tip positioned in the SVC
 under fluoroscopic guidance. Position of the catheter was confirmed by
 fluoroscopic spot film of the chest. The peel-away sheath and guidewire were
 then removed. The catheter was secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile
 dressing applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Limited venogram demonstrating stenosis at right axillary-subclavian vein
 junction which was traversed with a 0.018 Glidewire.
 2.  Placement of single lumen PICC line via the right brachial venous approach
 with final internal length of 43 cm and tip positioned in the SVC.  The line
 is ready for use.
                                                             (Over)

 [**2194-1-27**] 7:40 AM
 PICC LINE PLACMENT SCH                                          Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14610**]
 Reason: Please place IR-guided PICC for abx
 Admitting Diagnosis: HYPOTENSION
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 20
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)

Received 0.5 mg ativan and 2mg IV morphine for agitation.

Pt was admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 153**] where she completed a 10-day course of
ceftazadime and vancomycin for urosepsis. A 7-day course of
metronidazole was also completed for empiric treatment of C.
Diff given loose stools in the setting of an elevated WBC count,
although all C. Diff assays were negative. Pt was stabilized and
was transferred to the floor for further care. At the time of
transfer, active issues were poor nutritional status,
thrombocytopenia and anemia.

On the floor, however, pt experienced an episode of new Afib
with RVR to 160s and hypotension to SBP 90-100s, as well as
respiratory distress after she received fluid resuscitation.
There was also a concern for tachy-brady syndrome because she
had pauses up to 4 sec on telemetry; EP curbside, however, felt
digoxin was not recommended.

Pt was therefore readmitted to the MICU.  While in the MICU, she
was started on vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam as she had
(1) sites of possible infection at the erosions under her
breasts and on her right hip, as well as question of PNA, (2)
rising WBC, reaching a high of nearly 17.  MICU course was also
marked by (1) hypotension, which responded to gentle NS boluses;
(2) low UOP believed to be [**2-22**] both hypovolemia and a low
baseline nitrogenous load/obligate urine output; and (3)
recurrent Afib, for which she was transitioned to amiodarone
400mg PO daily, to run for 7 days before titrating downward.

Brief Hospital Course:
[**Age over 90 **]F with Nodular Sclerosing Hodgkin's Lymphoma initially
admitted for urosepsis, and who was transferred to the ICU with
hypotension and AFib with RVR.

# Goals of Care: The patient had a long hospital course with
many family meetings reagarding goals of care.  On [**2194-1-21**] the
patient was made DNR/DNI but the family continued to want ICU
transfers and pressors if needed, regardless of comfort to the
patient.  The patient was tranferred to the unit on [**2194-1-30**].
She was started on levophed for hypotension but eventually a
decision was made that it was medically futile to escalate care.
 Care was not escalated and she expired at 14:26 on [**2194-2-2**].
The family declined autopsy.

# Afib with RVR: Pt experienced transient episodes of Afib to
150's controlled with diltiazem and metoprolol, with spontaneous
conversion but with multiple episodes of up to 4 second pauses
and bradycardia to 40, likely junctional escape.  Digoxin
considered unfavorable in this patient.  In the MICU, pt was
started on amiodarone gtt, and converted to amiodarone PO.  When
the patient was readmitted to the ICU on [**2194-1-30**], she was having
increased pauses up to 20 seconds.  Her amiodarone was stopped.


# Thrombocytopenia/Anemia: The patient was anemia and
thrombocytopenic throughout the admission thought to be
secondary to marrow infiltration of lymphoma. Was transfused
total of 3 units PLT (1 unit each on [**1-14**] and [**1-19**])
with a transfusion threshold of 10. Will continue to trend
platelets, transfuse for bleeding or platelet count < 10.
Transfused 1 unit platelets with good bump on [**1-25**].  Also, the
patient has been receiving pRBC transfusions for HCT <24 (total
of four units since [**2194-1-12**]).

# Hypotension: Early on in the admission, she was having
hypotensive episodes after furosemide but was responsive to
fluid blosues of 250 cc.  ECHO demonstrated impaired LV
relaxation and given elevated WBC, there was concern for
distributive shock.  Once no longer fluid responsive, she was
started on phenylephrine gtt, which was weaned off.  She was
again hypotension later in her admission thought to be secondary
to systemic vasodilation.  She was started on levophed but a
decision was then made to not escalate care.

# Infection: WBC elevated with multiple possible infectious
sources which could contribute to hypotension (ie, skin erosions
under breasts, course breath sounds with ?PNA).  Vanc and piptaz
started on [**1-22**]; cultures of blood and urine pending; sputum not
obtainable at this point.  CDiff repeated with toxin B. C Diff
neg, thus D/C flagyl [**1-24**].  Now with GNR from skin swab.

# Hypernatremia: Noted to be periodically hypernatremic since
admission (Na 148-150), due to free water defecit. She has been
getting slow infusions of D5W as she has poor po intake and have
not been able to keep up her free water intake.

# Altered Mental Status: Increased lethargy compared to baseline
on admission most likely [**2-22**] metabolic encephalopathy due to
infection and acute renal failure, with slight improvement after
resolution of urosepsis. Head CT negative for acute process.
Thyroid studies show elevated TSH but this may be c/w sick
euthyroid syndrome.

# Respiratory Distress: Early in her admission, the patient
developed labored breathing after receiving 1 L NS for
hypotension c/w flash pulmonary edema.  Diuresis with furosemide
gtt lead to hypotension; albumin resuscitation lead to repeated
respiratory distress.  On [**2194-1-30**] she was on the floor and had a
witnessed aspiration event and needed 100% Hi Flow mask.  While
in the ICU her O2 was weaned but again aspirated and had
increasing O2 requirements.

# Acute renal failure: Pt noted to have Cr up to 1.7 on
admission from presumed baseline of 1.0, returned to baseline of
0.9. Likely was pre-renal due to dehydration and hypotension due
to sepsis.  Later in her hospital course, the patient was
hypotensive and her creatinine again began to rise thought
secondary to ATN.

# Hypothyroidism:  Initially treated with levothyroxine 12.5 mcg
IV daily (half home dose).  T3 low. TSH elevated.  Resumed home
dose 1/4.

# Anasarca: Pt has diffuse edema and large bilateral pleural
effusions likely third-spacing from malnutrition given low
albumin (2.8 on admission, then 2.2) and poor po intake.
Diuresis has been difficult due to hypotension as detailed
above.  Continue to monitor.

# Urosepsis: Admitted with hypotension due to urosepsis
requiring pressor support. Urine cultures from [**1-9**] were
positive for E.coli, and pt completed treated with vancomycin
and ceftazidime x10 days.  Repeat UCx [**2194-1-19**] grew out yeast,
which was not treated.  Another repeat UCx [**1-22**] final again grew
out yeast.

# Right Hip pain: Pain due to destruction of the right
acetabulum consistent with progressive lymphoma on CT scan.
There is dramatic medial displacement of the right femoral head
secondary to lack of remaining osseous support. Stable
destruction of the right posterior sacroiliac joint and
surrounding right sacral ala and iliac bone. The patient's pain
is being controlled with fentanyl and lidocaine patches.

# Bilateral pleural effusion: R>L, thought most likely due to
agressive hydration in the setting of sepsis and
hypoalbuminemia.  Was difficult to effect a significant diurese
in MICU due to development of hypotension in response to
furosemide. Appears slightly improved on CXR from [**2194-1-17**],
unchanged on [**1-20**] CXR.

# Nodular Sclerosing Hodgkin's Lymphoma: Seen by oncology, no
interventions at this time. Likely with bone marrow infiltration
causing anemia and thrombocytopenia above, as pt with low retic
count and no evidence of hemolysis.  No further treatment per
oncology.

# Coagulopathy: Mild, likely due to nutritional deficiency.
Encourage PO intake and trend LFTs, coags.

[**2194-1-11**] 1:01 PM
 CT CHEST W/O CONTRAST; CT ABDOMEN W/O CONTRAST                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14608**]
 CT PELVIS W/O CONTRAST
 Reason: concern for renal stone, pulmonary process
 Admitting Diagnosis: HYPOTENSION
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  [**Age over 90 **] year old woman with urosepsis, persistently hypotensive despite appropriate
  antibiotic therapy
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  concern for renal stone, pulmonary process
 CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST:
  renal failure
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 STUDY:  CT torso.

 INDICATION:  [**Age over 90 **]-year-old female with urosepsis and persistent hypotensive
 state despite appropriate antibiotic therapy.  Please evaluate for urinary
 tract obstruction/stone or pulmonary process.

 COMPARISON:  [**2193-9-4**].

 TECHNIQUE:  MDCT axially acquired images were obtained from the thoracic inlet
 to the symphysis without intravenous contrast administration.  Multiplanar
 reconstructed images were obtained.

 CT OF THE CHEST WITHOUT INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST:  There are bilateral pleural
 effusions with associated relaxation atelectasis, right greater than left,
 which have increased in size since previous study.  No definite focal
 infiltrate is identified. There is stable atherosclerotic plaque within the
 aorta which is not opacified with contrast. A left internal jugular central
 venous catheter tip terminates in the distal SVC. Stable dense coronary artery
 calcifications are again noted.  No pneumothorax is present. There is a stable
 noncalcified opacity within the left apex (2:11), measuring 8 mm and is
 stable, likely representing scar.  The major airways are patent down to the
 subsegmental level.  Although difficult to evaluate given lack of IV contrast,
 there is no significant increase in axillary or mediastinal adenopathy with
 the largest right axillary lymph node measuring 9 mm.  There is increased
 anasarca and a new simple appearing fluid collection surrounding the right
 pectoralis musculature.

 CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITHOUT IV CONTRAST:  Multiple hypodense lesions within the
 liver are again noted despite lack of IV contrast.  The gallbladder is
 distended without pericholecystic fluid or appreciable wall thickening.  The
 spleen, pancreas, and large and small bowel are unremarkable.  There is a
 stable cyst within the interpolar region of the right kidney.  No
 hydronephrosis, hydroureter or genitourinary calculi present.  The abdominal
 aorta is not focally dilated, although heavily calcified with atherosclerotic
 plaque, including the iliac vessels.  No free air or free fluid within the
 abdomen.

 CT PELVIS WITHOUT CONTRAST:  A Foley catheter is present within the bladder
                                                             (Over)

 [**2194-1-11**] 1:01 PM
 CT CHEST W/O CONTRAST; CT ABDOMEN W/O CONTRAST                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14608**]
 CT PELVIS W/O CONTRAST
 Reason: concern for renal stone, pulmonary process
 Admitting Diagnosis: HYPOTENSION
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
 which is mildly distended with air.  There is an atrophic calcified uterus
 which is not significantly changed in appearance.  A small amount of free
 pelvic fluid.  No free air is identified within the pelvis.

 OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:  There has been dramatic further destruction of the right
 acetabulum with an associated soft tissue mass and medial displacement of the
 femoral head through the bony defect. Soft tissue mass destructing the
 posterior aspect of the right sacroiliac joint and surrounding sacrum and
 ilium is not significantly changed, consistent with known lymphomatous
 destruction. S shaped thoracolumbar scoliosis.

 IMPRESSION:

 1.  Air within the bladder likely secondary to introduction from Foley
 catheter rather than emphysematous cystitis.  No renal stones or
 hydronephrosis.  Stable right renal cyst.

 2.  Increased size of right greater than left pleural effusion and associated
 relaxation atelectasis.

 3.  New small simple appearing fluid collection surronding the right
 pectoralis muscle.

 4.  Increased destruction of the right acetabulum consistent with progressive
 lymphoma.  There is dramatic medial displacement of the right femoral head
 secondary to lack of remaining osseous support. Stable destruction of the
 right posterior sacroiliac joint and surrounding right sacral ala and iliac
 bone.

 5.  Increased anasarca.

 6.  Diffuse aortic atherosclerotic plaque and coronary artery calcification.

Pt was admitted to [**Hospital Ward Name **] 4 on [**1-8**] after her home health aid found her to be confused and hypotensive.  She was treated for ureosepsis and hypotension for 10 days before being transfered to [**Hospital Ward Name 54**] 7. Technical Quality: Adequate


INTERPRETATION:

Findings:

This study was compared to the prior study of [**2194-1-8**].


LEFT ATRIUM: Mild LA enlargement.

RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: Normal RA size. Normal interatrial septum. No
ASD by 2D or color Doppler.

LEFT VENTRICLE: Normal LV wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global
systolic function (LVEF >55%). No resting LVOT gradient. No VSD.

RIGHT VENTRICLE: Normal RV chamber size and free wall motion.

AORTA: Normal aortic diameter at the sinus level. Mildly dilated ascending
aorta. No 2D or Doppler evidence of distal arch coarctation.

AORTIC VALVE: Mildly thickened aortic valve leaflets (3). No AS. Trace AR.

MITRAL VALVE: Mildly thickened mitral valve leaflets. Trivial MR. LV inflow
pattern c/w impaired relaxation.

TRICUSPID VALVE: Normal tricuspid valve leaflets with trivial TR.
Indeterminate PA systolic pressure.

PULMONIC VALVE/PULMONARY ARTERY: No PS.

PERICARDIUM: No pericardial effusion.

Conclusions:
The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or
color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and
regional/global systolic function are normal (LVEF >55%) There is no
ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion
are normal. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets
(3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace aortic
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Trivial
mitral regurgitation is seen. The left ventricular inflow pattern suggests
impaired relaxation. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be
determined. There is no pericardial effusion.

 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  [**Age over 90 **] year old woman with anasarca, hypotension, receiving abx
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Please place IR-guided PICC for abx
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  [**Age over 90 **]-year-old female receiving antibiotics.

 The procedure was explained to the patient.  A preprocedural timeout was
 performed.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 353**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) **] performed the procedure.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **],
 the attending radiologist, was present and supervising.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copy ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, attempts were
 made to advance the guidewire into the SVC.  The guidewire would not advance
 past the axillary vein and therefore a peel-away sheath was placed and a
 venogram performed demonstrating a short, tight stenosis at the right
 axillary/ subclavian vein junction.

 The area of stenosis was traversed under fluoroscopic guidance using a 0.018
 Glidewire.  A repeat venogram demonstrated a small amount of extravasated
 extraluminal contrast; however, the Glidewire was subsequently successfully
 navigated into the SVC.  A single lumen PICC line measuring 43 cm in length
 was then placed through the peel-away sheath with tip positioned in the SVC
 under fluoroscopic guidance. Position of the catheter was confirmed by
 fluoroscopic spot film of the chest. The peel-away sheath and guidewire were
 then removed. The catheter was secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile
 dressing applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Limited venogram demonstrating stenosis at right axillary-subclavian vein
 junction which was traversed with a 0.018 Glidewire.
 2.  Placement of single lumen PICC line via the right brachial venous approach
 with final internal length of 43 cm and tip positioned in the SVC.  The line
 is ready for use.
                                                             (Over)

Admission Date:  [**2194-1-7**]              Discharge Date:   [**2194-2-2**]


Service: MEDICINE

Allergies:
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs

Attending:[**Last Name (NamePattern4) 290**]
Chief Complaint:
Altered Mental Status and hypotension

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

History of Present Illness:
[**Age over 90 **]F Russian-speaking h/o refractory nodular sclerosing Hodgkins
Lymphoma was brought in by EMS and admitted after her home
health care aide noted she was hypotensive to 88/40 and
confused.

In the ED, T 98.4 (rectal), HR 101, BP 102/53, RR 20, O2Sat 98%
on 3L. Incontinant of guaiac-positive stool.  Treated with 4 L
NS, vanco 1g IV, ceftazadime 1g IV, and flagyl 500mg IV.
Received 0.5 mg ativan and 2mg IV morphine for agitation.

Pt was admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 153**] where she completed a 10-day course of
ceftazadime and vancomycin for urosepsis. A 7-day course of
metronidazole was also completed for empiric treatment of C.
Diff given loose stools in the setting of an elevated WBC count,
although all C. Diff assays were negative. Pt was stabilized and
was transferred to the floor for further care. At the time of
transfer, active issues were poor nutritional status,
thrombocytopenia and anemia.

On the floor, however, pt experienced an episode of new Afib
with RVR to 160s and hypotension to SBP 90-100s, as well as
respiratory distress after she received fluid resuscitation.
There was also a concern for tachy-brady syndrome because she
had pauses up to 4 sec on telemetry; EP curbside, however, felt
digoxin was not recommended.

Pt was therefore readmitted to the MICU.  While in the MICU, she
was started on vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam as she had
(1) sites of possible infection at the erosions under her
breasts and on her right hip, as well as question of PNA, (2)
rising WBC, reaching a high of nearly 17.  MICU course was also
marked by (1) hypotension, which responded to gentle NS boluses;
(2) low UOP believed to be [**2-22**] both hypovolemia and a low
baseline nitrogenous load/obligate urine output; and (3)
recurrent Afib, for which she was transitioned to amiodarone
400mg PO daily, to run for 7 days before titrating downward.

Past Medical History:
# Nodular sclerosing Hodgkins Lymphoma ([**3-/2188**])
--Presentation: Inguinal lymphadenopathy, treated with local
radiotherapy initially with good results.
--CT [**8-23**]: Progression, treated with Cytoxan, Velban and
Prednisone with a good response
--Eroding mass at sacrum, treated with radiation therapy
--[**3-/2191**]: Severe hypoxemia, somnolence, and generalized edema,
with anasarca responsive to diuresis and oxygen supplements, and
discharged on constant oxygen
--[**3-/2191**]: CVVP trial, stopped in [**10-28**] because of low blood
counts
--Low-dose modified regimen: Chlorambucil 4mg daily for days
[**1-27**], Procarbazine 50mg daily for days [**1-27**], Velban 10 mg IV on
day 1 only, Neulasta 6mg on day 8.
--[**9-/2192**]: Chemotherapy discontinued given poor response
--[**1-/2193**]: L sided chest pain with lytic lesions in the thoracic
vertebrae; received radiation therapy to T6-T8 including the
right 7th rib
--CT [**8-/2193**]: Interval decrease in vertebral lesions.

# Lower extremity cellulitis
# GERD
# Arthritis
# Chronic BLE edema
# Hypothyroidism
# Hypertension
# Constipation

Social History:
Lives at home with health care aide.  Son [**Name (NI) **] very involved in
her care.  Three children. No tobacco, alcohol, and illicit drug
use.


Family History:
Noncontributory

Physical Exam:
Initial Physical Exam
GENERAL: Elderly female in no acute distress. Minimally
reponsive to verbal stimuli but very responsive to tactile
stimulation.
VITALS: T 98.8 Rectal HR 79 BP 104/67 RR 15 SAT 97%4L NC
HEENT: Sclera anicteric. Moist mucous membranes.
NECK: 2+ carotid pulses. No LAD.No JVP elevation.
CHEST: Lungs Clear Anteriorly and laterally. No axillary LAD.
HEART: Regular. No murmurs.
ABD: Soft, non distended, quiet bowel sounds, non tender to
percussion.
EXT: Pitting edema of feet bilaterally. Nonpalpable pulses. Feet
cool. Reasonable capillary refill bilaterally.
NEURO: Sleepy but arousable. Pupils 1-2mm bilaterally. Withdraws
from painful stimuli. Good strength. Increased Tone. Mute
reflexes bilaterally. Toes mute bilaterally.

Physical Exam at Time of Transfer to Medical Floor
VITALS: T 97.1  P 96  R 24  100/60  94% 2L NC
GENERAL: Elderly female in no acute distress. Minimally
reponsive to verbal stimuli but arousable with tactile
stimulation.
HEENT: Sclera anicteric. Dry mucous membranes.
NECK: 2+ carotid pulses. No LAD. No JVP elevation.
CHEST: Diminished breath sounds at bases bilaterally. No
axillary LAD.
HEART: Regular. No murmurs.
ABD: Soft, distended, active bowel sounds, non tender to
percussion.
EXT: Pitting edema of all extremities bilaterally. Nonpalpable
pulses. Feet cool. Reasonable capillary refill bilaterally.
NEURO: Sleepy but arousable. Pupils 3-4mm bilaterally. Withdraws
from painful stimuli. Diminished reflexes bilaterally
throughout.

Physical Exam upon transfer to MICU:
VS: Temp: 98.1 BP: 87/35 HR: 102 RR: 31 O2sat 94% 2 LNC
GEN: pleasant, comfortable, NAD, somewhat somnolent (falling
asleep during the exam)
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI, anicteric, tachy MM, op without lesions
NECK: no supraclavicular or cervical lymphadenopathy, no jvd
RESP: occ. crackle at bases, though difficult to assess b/c
patient not cooperative during the exam
CV: RR, no m/r/g
ABD: nd, +b/s, soft, nt, no masses or hepatosplenomegaly
EXT: warm, + anasarca with involvement of upper limbs
SKIN: no rashes, no jaundice
NEURO: somewhat somnolent. Cn II-XII grossly intact. Difficult
to complete full neuro exam given somnolence

Pertinent Results:
[**1-8**] - CXR - IMPRESSION: Persistent right-sided effusion. No
definite consolidation. Routine PA and lateral films are
recommended for evaluation when feasible.

[**1-10**].  Echo.
The left atrium is normal in size. No atrial septal defect is
seen by 2D or color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thicknesses
are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Overall
left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). Right
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The
aortic valve leaflets (probably 3) are mildly thickened. There
is no aortic valve stenosis. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen.
The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Physiologic
mitral regurgitation is seen (within normal limits). There is
moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no
pericardial effusion.

Based on [**2193**] AHA endocarditis prophylaxis recommendations, the
echo findings indicate prophylaxis is NOT recommended. Clinical
decisions regarding the need for prophylaxis should be based on
clinical and echocardiographic data.

Compared with the report of the prior study (images unavailable
for review) of [**2190-12-22**], there is no definite change.

Brief Hospital Course:
[**Age over 90 **]F with Nodular Sclerosing Hodgkin's Lymphoma initially
admitted for urosepsis, and who was transferred to the ICU with
hypotension and AFib with RVR.

# Goals of Care: The patient had a long hospital course with
many family meetings reagarding goals of care.  On [**2194-1-21**] the
patient was made DNR/DNI but the family continued to want ICU
transfers and pressors if needed, regardless of comfort to the
patient.  The patient was tranferred to the unit on [**2194-1-30**].
She was started on levophed for hypotension but eventually a
decision was made that it was medically futile to escalate care.
 Care was not escalated and she expired at 14:26 on [**2194-2-2**].
The family declined autopsy.

# Afib with RVR: Pt experienced transient episodes of Afib to
150's controlled with diltiazem and metoprolol, with spontaneous
conversion but with multiple episodes of up to 4 second pauses
and bradycardia to 40, likely junctional escape.  Digoxin
considered unfavorable in this patient.  In the MICU, pt was
started on amiodarone gtt, and converted to amiodarone PO.  When
the patient was readmitted to the ICU on [**2194-1-30**], she was having
increased pauses up to 20 seconds.  Her amiodarone was stopped.


# Thrombocytopenia/Anemia: The patient was anemia and
thrombocytopenic throughout the admission thought to be
secondary to marrow infiltration of lymphoma. Was transfused
total of 3 units PLT (1 unit each on [**1-14**] and [**1-19**])
with a transfusion threshold of 10. Will continue to trend
platelets, transfuse for bleeding or platelet count < 10.
Transfused 1 unit platelets with good bump on [**1-25**].  Also, the
patient has been receiving pRBC transfusions for HCT <24 (total
of four units since [**2194-1-12**]).

# Hypotension: Early on in the admission, she was having
hypotensive episodes after furosemide but was responsive to
fluid blosues of 250 cc.  ECHO demonstrated impaired LV
relaxation and given elevated WBC, there was concern for
distributive shock.  Once no longer fluid responsive, she was
started on phenylephrine gtt, which was weaned off.  She was
again hypotension later in her admission thought to be secondary
to systemic vasodilation.  She was started on levophed but a
decision was then made to not escalate care.

# Infection: WBC elevated with multiple possible infectious
sources which could contribute to hypotension (ie, skin erosions
under breasts, course breath sounds with ?PNA).  Vanc and piptaz
started on [**1-22**]; cultures of blood and urine pending; sputum not
obtainable at this point.  CDiff repeated with toxin B. C Diff
neg, thus D/C flagyl [**1-24**].  Now with GNR from skin swab.

# Hypernatremia: Noted to be periodically hypernatremic since
admission (Na 148-150), due to free water defecit. She has been
getting slow infusions of D5W as she has poor po intake and have
not been able to keep up her free water intake.

# Altered Mental Status: Increased lethargy compared to baseline
on admission most likely [**2-22**] metabolic encephalopathy due to
infection and acute renal failure, with slight improvement after
resolution of urosepsis. Head CT negative for acute process.
Thyroid studies show elevated TSH but this may be c/w sick
euthyroid syndrome.

# Respiratory Distress: Early in her admission, the patient
developed labored breathing after receiving 1 L NS for
hypotension c/w flash pulmonary edema.  Diuresis with furosemide
gtt lead to hypotension; albumin resuscitation lead to repeated
respiratory distress.  On [**2194-1-30**] she was on the floor and had a
witnessed aspiration event and needed 100% Hi Flow mask.  While
in the ICU her O2 was weaned but again aspirated and had
increasing O2 requirements.

# Acute renal failure: Pt noted to have Cr up to 1.7 on
admission from presumed baseline of 1.0, returned to baseline of
0.9. Likely was pre-renal due to dehydration and hypotension due
to sepsis.  Later in her hospital course, the patient was
hypotensive and her creatinine again began to rise thought
secondary to ATN.

# Hypothyroidism:  Initially treated with levothyroxine 12.5 mcg
IV daily (half home dose).  T3 low. TSH elevated.  Resumed home
dose 1/4.

# Anasarca: Pt has diffuse edema and large bilateral pleural
effusions likely third-spacing from malnutrition given low
albumin (2.8 on admission, then 2.2) and poor po intake.
Diuresis has been difficult due to hypotension as detailed
above.  Continue to monitor.

# Urosepsis: Admitted with hypotension due to urosepsis
requiring pressor support. Urine cultures from [**1-9**] were
positive for E.coli, and pt completed treated with vancomycin
and ceftazidime x10 days.  Repeat UCx [**2194-1-19**] grew out yeast,
which was not treated.  Another repeat UCx [**1-22**] final again grew
out yeast.

# Right Hip pain: Pain due to destruction of the right
acetabulum consistent with progressive lymphoma on CT scan.
There is dramatic medial displacement of the right femoral head
secondary to lack of remaining osseous support. Stable
destruction of the right posterior sacroiliac joint and
surrounding right sacral ala and iliac bone. The patient's pain
is being controlled with fentanyl and lidocaine patches.

# Bilateral pleural effusion: R>L, thought most likely due to
agressive hydration in the setting of sepsis and
hypoalbuminemia.  Was difficult to effect a significant diurese
in MICU due to development of hypotension in response to
furosemide. Appears slightly improved on CXR from [**2194-1-17**],
unchanged on [**1-20**] CXR.

# Nodular Sclerosing Hodgkin's Lymphoma: Seen by oncology, no
interventions at this time. Likely with bone marrow infiltration
causing anemia and thrombocytopenia above, as pt with low retic
count and no evidence of hemolysis.  No further treatment per
oncology.

# Coagulopathy: Mild, likely due to nutritional deficiency.
Encourage PO intake and trend LFTs, coags.

 calcifications are again noted.  No pneumothorax is present. There is a stable

 subsegmental level.  Although difficult to evaluate given lack of IV contrast,

 anasarca and a new simple appearing fluid collection surrounding the right
 pectoralis musculature.

 CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITHOUT IV CONTRAST:  Multiple hypodense lesions within the
 liver are again noted despite lack of IV contrast.  The gallbladder is
 distended without pericholecystic fluid or appreciable wall thickening.  The
 spleen, pancreas, and large and small bowel are unremarkable.  There is a
 stable cyst within the interpolar region of the right kidney.  No
 hydronephrosis, hydroureter or genitourinary calculi present.  The abdominal
 aorta is not focally dilated, although heavily calcified with atherosclerotic
 plaque, including the iliac vessels.  No free air or free fluid within the
 abdomen.

PATIENT/TEST INFORMATION:
Indication: Left ventricular function. New afib with RVR.
Height: (in) 63
Weight (lb): 152
BSA (m2): 1.72 m2
BP (mm Hg): 95/46
HR (bpm): 82
Status: Inpatient
Date/Time: [**2194-1-22**] at 14:30
Test: Portable TTE (Complete)
Doppler: Full Doppler and color Doppler
Contrast: None
Technical Quality: Adequate


INTERPRETATION:

Findings:

This study was compared to the prior study of [**2194-1-8**].


LEFT ATRIUM: Mild LA enlargement.

RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: Normal RA size. Normal interatrial septum. No
ASD by 2D or color Doppler.

LEFT VENTRICLE: Normal LV wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global
systolic function (LVEF >55%). No resting LVOT gradient. No VSD.

RIGHT VENTRICLE: Normal RV chamber size and free wall motion.

AORTA: Normal aortic diameter at the sinus level. Mildly dilated ascending
aorta. No 2D or Doppler evidence of distal arch coarctation.

AORTIC VALVE: Mildly thickened aortic valve leaflets (3). No AS. Trace AR.

MITRAL VALVE: Mildly thickened mitral valve leaflets. Trivial MR. LV inflow
pattern c/w impaired relaxation.

TRICUSPID VALVE: Normal tricuspid valve leaflets with trivial TR.
Indeterminate PA systolic pressure.

PULMONIC VALVE/PULMONARY ARTERY: No PS.

PERICARDIUM: No pericardial effusion.

Conclusions:
The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or
color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and
regional/global systolic function are normal (LVEF >55%) There is no
ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion
are normal. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets
(3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace aortic
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Trivial
mitral regurgitation is seen. The left ventricular inflow pattern suggests
impaired relaxation. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be
determined. There is no pericardial effusion.

Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2194-1-8**], no change.

text.1615018:
0700-1900  MICU PROGRESS NOTE

[**Age over 90 **] yo female admitted originally on [**1-8**] to [**Hospital Ward Name **] 4 w/ urosepsis and hypotension.  Pt spent 10 days in ICU and then was transferred to [**Hospital Ward Name 54**].  ON [**1-21**] pt developed hypotension on floor and increased sommulence.  Team met w/ family and pt was made DNR/DNI, but wants full treatment.  See care-vue for PMH.

[**Name (NI) **]  Pt is alert today, but unable to fully assess neuro function secondary to [**Doctor Last Name **] barrier.  Grand-daughter in this evening and able to converse with pt, states she is appropriate and able to follow simple commands.

C/V-  neo increased this am for decreasing B/P..highest dose 1.6mcg/kg/hr.  Pt given albumin X 2 doses..B/P increased and Neo titrated down and d/c'd at 7pm.  Pt has + 4 edema and anasarca.

Resp-  Lungs remained dininished until 7pm , at that time pt became hypoxic..sat's dropped to the 80's.  Pt wheezing and crackles at bases w/ RR 30's.  Pt placed on NRB mask and team notified,  sat's increased to 98-100% on 100% NRB.  CXR ordered

Abd-  Abd soft, +BS..No stool noted.  Started on prophalysis tx of CDIFF w/ po Flagyl.   Eats about 50% of meals

Skin-  Multi areas of bruising and eccymosis.  B heels reddened/ blueish..doppler pulses only.

Plan
Monitor resp status
Monitor electrolytes
Skin care as ordered

text.1615019:
MICU 6 NPN 1900-0700

At beginning of shift pt began to desat to 80s on 3L NC, HR up to 100s NSR with RR low 30s.  She was put on NRB with improvement is sats.  Fine crackles noted in bases, R>L, CXR obtainned.  PT's RR and HR began to improve and she was weanned down to 6L O2 NC with no medical interventions.  AT 2100 pt went into rapid Afib with HR 100s-110s, [** **] was obtainned, BP down to 85/46.  She was restarted on Neo and given 5 mg IV lopressor.  After 30 minutes pt still in A.fib and began to have pauses, with longest pause 5.5 seconds. At 2300, pt back into NSR with no further pauses, Neo continued and increased for MAP greater than 65, Currently at 1.5 mcg/kg/hr.

Neuro:  Pt alert with spontaneous eye openning.  Unable to obtain orientation [**2-22**] [**Month/Day (2) 838**] speaking only.  PERL brisk.  MAE with equal strength bilat.  During night pt moanning loudly and was given 1 mg IV Morphine x3 with some effect.  She also had fent patch on and lidocaine patch was removed this shift.

CV:  See note above.  NBP range 85/46-115/56 with MAPS 55-69.  Neo at 1.5 mcg/kg/hr.  HR 80-110s NSR with one episode RAfib.  occ PVCs.

Resp:  PT currently on 3L O2 NC with sats 95%.  She was given 1 alb neb by RN for exp wheezes throughout.  Pos cough is worsenning, team aware.  She does not have sputum.

GI/GU:  ABd is firm and distended, hypoactive bowel sounds.  She has colace and senna [**Hospital1 **] and was given dulcolax PO in PM.  no BM this shift.  FOley patent drainning clear yellow urine.  low UOP, team aware

Skin:  PT with mulitple skin issues.  She itches abd frequently and Sarna lotion has been applied.  Breast excoriated and antifungal cream applied.  BLE in waffle boots.  +3 gen body edema.

ID: Tmax, 98.7 Ax, IV vanco, IV Zosyn, PO flagyl

Social:  1 son in to visit briefly in PM, MD did speak to son when he was here.

Plan:
Routine ICU monitorring
Continue to assess for pain
Monitor skin, apply Sarna as needed.
Monitor labs
MOnitor HR and NBP, titrate Neo for MAP >65.
text.1615309:
Nursing Progress note 0700-1900
Events: [**Name (NI) 52**] pt on amiodarone qtt S/P RAF overnight. Pt converted to SR @ 0915, and able to wean off Neosynephrine 1hr later.

Review of systems:

Neuro: Pt remains lethargic, opening eyes spont, O X 1 per [**Name (NI) 838**] speaking family. Pt consistantly denies pain per family, but groans when turned STS.  Lidocaine, Fentanyl patches in place. Gag remains marginal, with aspiration precautions in place and freq inforced to family. Cough present but weak, non-productive. Pt OOB to chair via [**Doctor Last Name **], tolerated it well X 6hrs.

Resp: Pt has remained on 3l NC with O2 sat 95-100%, RR 23-36 and regular. Pt with congested cough. Lung snds initially clear in upper lobes, now more coarse bilat. Lower lobe snds remain diminished.

CV: Per above rec'd pt on amiodarone qtt @ 0.5mg/min (to be D/C'd @ 2330 tonight), Neosynephrine qtt @ 0.5mcg/kg/min. At 0915 pt converted from AFib rate 80-90's to SR rate 65-80's. BP increased from SBP 90's to 115/59-145/71, and Neosyneph D/C'd @ 1020. Ionized Ca 1.08 in am not repleted per team, sliding scale d/C'd. Hct stable @ 1400 @ 24.5.
Pt rec'd NS fluid bolus of 250ml for low urine output with scant increase in urine. CVP 8-11. Pronounced periph edema persists.

GI: Abd firm/distended with hypoactive BS. Pt occas seen to rub abd but denies pain. Pt with poor appetite for soft solid diet, taking mostly yogurt from son. [**Name (NI) **] BM this shift.

GU: Urine yellow with sed, draining in small amts(4-15ml/hr) even after fluid bolus per above.  24hr fluid balance + 977ml @ 1700, with LOS balance + 24liters.

ID: Afebrile. Pt cont on Zosyn, Vancomycin.

Skin: Abrasions in creases under breasts cleaned with wound cleanser, bacitracin applied, and DSD protecting from further abrasion. Pt cont to scratch, especially L hip which occas bleeds. Soft wrist restraints remain bilat, with mitts occas used to avoid scratching.

Access: All 3 ports of LIJ functioning after Alteplase infused.

Social: Sons both visited, anxious re mother getting sufficient nutrition while maintaining aspiration precautions as well as pt's poor appetite.

Plan: Cont strict aspiration precautions. Cont to monitor urine output. Mitts as needed to protect pt's skin. Amiodarone qtt off @ 2330. Cont emotional support to family and pt.

text.1618428:
Nursing Progress/Transfer Note 0700-1500
This [**Age over 90 **]yo [**Age over 90 838**]-speaking woman with PMH: Nodular Sclerosing Hodgkin's Lymphoma, HTN, Hypothyroidism, LE cellulitis, chronic bilat LE edema, GERD, arthritis, dementia. She presented to ED [**2194-1-7**] with hypotension and altered MS. [**First Name (Titles) 10292**] [**Last Name (Titles) **]'d and pt tx'd with antibiotics and pressors. Neo/Amio later used successfully when pt had hypotension assoc with RAF.

Review of Systems:

Neruo:  Pt naps frequently, but easily woken and alert. Family reports pt O X 1 (pt speaks [**Last Name (Titles) 838**] only but understands a few words English). Lidocaine and Fentanyl patches in place for chronic pain. Pt occas moans when moved but consistantly denies pain. OOB to chair via [**Doctor Last Name **] lift, tol well. Pt with weak dry cough, and aspiration precautions in place for ? impaired gag. Pt has passed speech/swallow test in the past, but now "hampsters" food and requires extended period to swallow. Family has refused GT for pt. Soft wrist restraints in place as pt attempts to remove NC and central line. She also has chronically itchy skin, despite liberal use of Sarna lotion, and will scratch R hip until skin bleeds.

Resp: O2 sat 96-100% on 2l NC with RR 16-24 and regular. Lung snds clear in upper lobes, diminished in bases. Pt with chronic dry cough.

CV: HR 64-72SR with rare ectopy. BP 117/54-139/56. AM Na 148-> pt rec'd 250ml fluid bolus X 2 of D5.45NS. Hct trending down to 23 this am, repeat pndg from 1400 as are lytes.

GI: Abd firm/distended with hypoactive BS. Pt with poor appetite on soft solid diet, taking only a few spoonfuls per meal. Liquid intake also very poor. Pt had lg guiaic neg BM last noc.

GU: Urine amber with sed, draining via foley @ 10-40ml/hr. LOS fluid balance +24.5liters.

Skin: Excoriated areas under breasts responding well to wound cleanser and antibacterials, with crease wnds closing. Areas padded with Kerlix. Heels protected with waffle boots. Hips R>L with many scratch marks from pt.

ID: Afebrile. Pt remains on Vancomycin, Zosyn.

Access: LIJ, with pt to be evaluated for a PICC. Periph IV not possible S/T edema.

Social: Sons, [**Name (NI) 10293**] very attentive to pt, freq attempting to feed her. Aspiration precautions freq reinforced. Palliative care consult order.

Plan: Pt remains DNR/DNI, with family opposed to GT. Transfer to floor. Cont aggressive aspiration precations. PT consult. PICC eval @ bedside. Cont emotional support to pt, family.

[**2194-1-27**] 7:40 AM
 PICC LINE PLACMENT SCH                                          Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14610**]
 Reason: Please place IR-guided PICC for abx
 Admitting Diagnosis: HYPOTENSION
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 20
 ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
 * [**Numeric Identifier 273**] PICC W/O [**Numeric Identifier 352**] FLUORO GUID PLCT/REPLCT/REMOVE   *
 * [**Numeric Identifier 9**] US GUID FOR VAS. ACCESS                                                *
 ****************************************************************************
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  [**Age over 90 **] year old woman with anasarca, hypotension, receiving abx
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Please place IR-guided PICC for abx
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  [**Age over 90 **]-year-old female receiving antibiotics.

 The procedure was explained to the patient.  A preprocedural timeout was
 performed.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 353**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) **] performed the procedure.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **],
 the attending radiologist, was present and supervising.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copy ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, attempts were
 made to advance the guidewire into the SVC.  The guidewire would not advance
 past the axillary vein and therefore a peel-away sheath was placed and a
 venogram performed demonstrating a short, tight stenosis at the right
 axillary/ subclavian vein junction.

 The area of stenosis was traversed under fluoroscopic guidance using a 0.018
 Glidewire.  A repeat venogram demonstrated a small amount of extravasated
 extraluminal contrast; however, the Glidewire was subsequently successfully
 navigated into the SVC.  A single lumen PICC line measuring 43 cm in length
 was then placed through the peel-away sheath with tip positioned in the SVC
 under fluoroscopic guidance. Position of the catheter was confirmed by
 fluoroscopic spot film of the chest. The peel-away sheath and guidewire were
 then removed. The catheter was secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile
 dressing applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Limited venogram demonstrating stenosis at right axillary-subclavian vein
 junction which was traversed with a 0.018 Glidewire.
 2.  Placement of single lumen PICC line via the right brachial venous approach
 with final internal length of 43 cm and tip positioned in the SVC.  The line
 is ready for use.
                                                             (Over)

 [**2194-1-27**] 7:40 AM
 PICC LINE PLACMENT SCH                                          Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14610**]
 Reason: Please place IR-guided PICC for abx
 Admitting Diagnosis: HYPOTENSION
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 20
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)

 INDICATION:  PICC line pulled out.  Intravenous antibiotics.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 3044**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 1231**] performed the procedure.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1231**],
 was supervising for the entire procedure.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  A preprocedure timeout was performed to confirm
 patient identity and the procedure to be performed.  Under fluoroscopic
 guidance, the right upper extremity and existing PICC line which had been
 pulled out approximately 8-10 cm were prepped and draped in standard sterile

 brachial vein approach.  Total internal length is 41 cm.  The line is now
 ready for use.

MICU 7 RN Note: 0700-1900

EVENTS: Pt expired.

NEURO:  Pt moaning between 7a-8a. Re-positioning was not effective. Morphine 2mg adm at 8am followed by another 2mg at 8:30am.  BP not affected.  Pt much less responsive today and scratching/moving arms less.  No additional Morphine was needed. Pt became unresponsive to stimuli except slight response to oral care.

CV:  HR stable with nearly no pausing as she had yesterday.  BP maintained at SBP>75 and MAP>50 until ~11am during rounds when BP dropped below 75 and MAP below 50.  Levophed was on 0.02mcg all shift. Son, [**Name (NI) **], arrived during rounds and expressed concern about the blood pressure being so low (80s/50s all morning); see Social. LIJ TL intact.  One port not patent.  Afebrile.  Skin care provided for skin tears, wounds, scratches, edema.  Bradycardia began to occur ~1400 w/associated drop in BP.  Levo  Asystole occurred at 1426 (monitor time).

RESP:  RR 18-20.  Lungs clear initially then coarse through after re-positioning from left side to right.  O2 sats on 3L NC began to drop; flow incr to 6L then NRB added.  Cannula taken off and Sats maintained in mid-high 90s with NRB alone.  Oral suctioned blood tinged oral secretions.  No frank blood seen.

GU:  Foley intact. UOP decreased to zero.

GI:  NG intact; large amount of residual.  TF off from before 7am.  NG placed to wall suction: 200ml.  -BS.  +BM just prior to/at time of death.

[**Location (un) **] Organ Bank to be notified by Admitting.

SOCIAL:  Fellow met with son, [**Name (NI) **], at bedside and explained pt's condition (pt would not recover regardless of pressor support/other treatment).  Decision was made not to withdraw care or to escalate.  Resident contact[**Name (NI) **] family when HR dropped below 60s and BP dropped to SBP 60s.  Family arrived after pt expired.  [**Doctor First Name **] asked how to make arrangements.  They have a funeral home chosen; phone number was provided to them.  They were advised to contact funeral home; that someone should be on-call; and that the funeral home would tell them what steps to take next.

Family still at bedside as of 1630.

Admission Date:  [**2194-1-7**]              Discharge Date:   [**2194-2-2**]


Service: MEDICINE

Allergies:
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs

Chief Complaint:
Altered Mental Status and hypotension

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

History of Present Illness:
[**Age over 90 **]F Russian-speaking h/o refractory nodular sclerosing Hodgkins
Lymphoma was brought in by EMS and admitted after her home
health care aide noted she was hypotensive to 88/40 and
confused.

In the ED, T 98.4 (rectal), HR 101, BP 102/53, RR 20, O2Sat 98%
on 3L. Incontinant of guaiac-positive stool.  Treated with 4 L
NS, vanco 1g IV, ceftazadime 1g IV, and flagyl 500mg IV.
Received 0.5 mg ativan and 2mg IV morphine for agitation.

Pt was admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 153**] where she completed a 10-day course of
ceftazadime and vancomycin for urosepsis. A 7-day course of
metronidazole was also completed for empiric treatment of C.
Diff given loose stools in the setting of an elevated WBC count,
although all C. Diff assays were negative. Pt was stabilized and
was transferred to the floor for further care. At the time of
transfer, active issues were poor nutritional status,
thrombocytopenia and anemia.

On the floor, however, pt experienced an episode of new Afib
with RVR to 160s and hypotension to SBP 90-100s, as well as
respiratory distress after she received fluid resuscitation.
There was also a concern for tachy-brady syndrome because she
had pauses up to 4 sec on telemetry; EP curbside, however, felt
digoxin was not recommended.

Pt was therefore readmitted to the MICU.  While in the MICU, she
was started on vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam as she had
(1) sites of possible infection at the erosions under her
breasts and on her right hip, as well as question of PNA, (2)
rising WBC, reaching a high of nearly 17.  MICU course was also
marked by (1) hypotension, which responded to gentle NS boluses;
(2) low UOP believed to be [**2-22**] both hypovolemia and a low
baseline nitrogenous load/obligate urine output; and (3)
recurrent Afib, for which she was transitioned to amiodarone
400mg PO daily, to run for 7 days before titrating downward.

Past Medical History:
# Nodular sclerosing Hodgkins Lymphoma ([**3-/2188**])
--Presentation: Inguinal lymphadenopathy, treated with local
radiotherapy initially with good results.
--CT [**8-23**]: Progression, treated with Cytoxan, Velban and
Prednisone with a good response
--Eroding mass at sacrum, treated with radiation therapy
--[**3-/2191**]: Severe hypoxemia, somnolence, and generalized edema,
with anasarca responsive to diuresis and oxygen supplements, and
discharged on constant oxygen
--[**3-/2191**]: CVVP trial, stopped in [**10-28**] because of low blood
counts
--Low-dose modified regimen: Chlorambucil 4mg daily for days
[**1-27**], Procarbazine 50mg daily for days [**1-27**], Velban 10 mg IV on
day 1 only, Neulasta 6mg on day 8.
--[**9-/2192**]: Chemotherapy discontinued given poor response
--[**1-/2193**]: L sided chest pain with lytic lesions in the thoracic
vertebrae; received radiation therapy to T6-T8 including the
right 7th rib
--CT [**8-/2193**]: Interval decrease in vertebral lesions.

# Lower extremity cellulitis
# GERD

# Chronic BLE edema
# Hypothyroidism
# Hypertension
# Constipation

Social History:
Lives at home with health care aide.  Son [**Name (NI) **] very involved in
her care.  Three children. No tobacco, alcohol, and illicit drug
use.


Family History:
Noncontributory

Physical Exam:
Initial Physical Exam
GENERAL: Elderly female in no acute distress. Minimally
reponsive to verbal stimuli but very responsive to tactile
stimulation.
VITALS: T 98.8 Rectal HR 79 BP 104/67 RR 15 SAT 97%4L NC
HEENT: Sclera anicteric. Moist mucous membranes.
NECK: 2+ carotid pulses. No LAD.No JVP elevation.

EXT: Pitting edema of feet bilaterally. Nonpalpable pulses. Feet

from painful stimuli. Good strength. Increased Tone. Mute

GENERAL: Elderly female in no acute distress. Minimally
reponsive to verbal stimuli but arousable with tactile
stimulation.
HEENT: Sclera anicteric. Dry mucous membranes.
NECK: 2+ carotid pulses. No LAD. No JVP elevation.
CHEST: Diminished breath sounds at bases bilaterally. No
axillary LAD.
HEART: Regular. No murmurs.
ABD: Soft, distended, active bowel sounds, non tender to
percussion.
EXT: Pitting edema of all extremities bilaterally. Nonpalpable
pulses. Feet cool. Reasonable capillary refill bilaterally.
NEURO: Sleepy but arousable. Pupils 3-4mm bilaterally. Withdraws
from painful stimuli. Diminished reflexes bilaterally
throughout.

Physical Exam upon transfer to MICU:
VS: Temp: 98.1 BP: 87/35 HR: 102 RR: 31 O2sat 94% 2 LNC
GEN: pleasant, comfortable, NAD, somewhat somnolent (falling
asleep during the exam)
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI, anicteric, tachy MM, op without lesions
NECK: no supraclavicular or cervical lymphadenopathy, no jvd
RESP: occ. crackle at bases, though difficult to assess b/c
patient not cooperative during the exam
CV: RR, no m/r/g
ABD: nd, +b/s, soft, nt, no masses or hepatosplenomegaly
EXT: warm, + anasarca with involvement of upper limbs
SKIN: no rashes, no jaundice
NEURO: somewhat somnolent. Cn II-XII grossly intact. Difficult
to complete full neuro exam given somnolence

Pertinent Results:
[**1-8**] - CXR - IMPRESSION: Persistent right-sided effusion. No
definite consolidation. Routine PA and lateral films are
recommended for evaluation when feasible.

[**1-10**].  Echo.
The left atrium is normal in size. No atrial septal defect is
seen by 2D or color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thicknesses
are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Overall
left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). Right
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The
aortic valve leaflets (probably 3) are mildly thickened. There
is no aortic valve stenosis. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen.
The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Physiologic
mitral regurgitation is seen (within normal limits). There is
moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no
pericardial effusion.

Based on [**2193**] AHA endocarditis prophylaxis recommendations, the
echo findings indicate prophylaxis is NOT recommended. Clinical
decisions regarding the need for prophylaxis should be based on
clinical and echocardiographic data.

Compared with the report of the prior study (images unavailable
for review) of [**2190-12-22**], there is no definite change.

Brief Hospital Course:
[**Age over 90 **]F with Nodular Sclerosing Hodgkin's Lymphoma initially
admitted for urosepsis, and who was transferred to the ICU with
hypotension and AFib with RVR.

# Goals of Care: The patient had a long hospital course with
many family meetings reagarding goals of care.  On [**2194-1-21**] the
patient was made DNR/DNI but the family continued to want ICU
transfers and pressors if needed, regardless of comfort to the
patient.  The patient was tranferred to the unit on [**2194-1-30**].
She was started on levophed for hypotension but eventually a
decision was made that it was medically futile to escalate care.
 Care was not escalated and she expired at 14:26 on [**2194-2-2**].
The family declined autopsy.

# Afib with RVR: Pt experienced transient episodes of Afib to
150's controlled with diltiazem and metoprolol, with spontaneous
conversion but with multiple episodes of up to 4 second pauses
and bradycardia to 40, likely junctional escape.  Digoxin
considered unfavorable in this patient.  In the MICU, pt was
started on amiodarone gtt, and converted to amiodarone PO.  When
the patient was readmitted to the ICU on [**2194-1-30**], she was having
increased pauses up to 20 seconds.  Her amiodarone was stopped.


# Thrombocytopenia/Anemia: The patient was anemia and
thrombocytopenic throughout the admission thought to be
secondary to marrow infiltration of lymphoma. Was transfused
total of 3 units PLT (1 unit each on [**1-14**] and [**1-19**])
with a transfusion threshold of 10. Will continue to trend
platelets, transfuse for bleeding or platelet count < 10.
Transfused 1 unit platelets with good bump on [**1-25**].  Also, the
patient has been receiving pRBC transfusions for HCT <24 (total
of four units since [**2194-1-12**]).

# Hypotension: Early on in the admission, she was having
hypotensive episodes after furosemide but was responsive to
fluid blosues of 250 cc.  ECHO demonstrated impaired LV
relaxation and given elevated WBC, there was concern for
distributive shock.  Once no longer fluid responsive, she was
started on phenylephrine gtt, which was weaned off.  She was
again hypotension later in her admission thought to be secondary
to systemic vasodilation.  She was started on levophed but a
decision was then made to not escalate care.

# Infection: WBC elevated with multiple possible infectious
sources which could contribute to hypotension (ie, skin erosions
under breasts, course breath sounds with ?PNA).  Vanc and piptaz
started on [**1-22**]; cultures of blood and urine pending; sputum not
obtainable at this point.  CDiff repeated with toxin B. C Diff
neg, thus D/C flagyl [**1-24**].  Now with GNR from skin swab.

# Hypernatremia: Noted to be periodically hypernatremic since
admission (Na 148-150), due to free water defecit. She has been
getting slow infusions of D5W as she has poor po intake and have
not been able to keep up her free water intake.

# Altered Mental Status: Increased lethargy compared to baseline
on admission most likely [**2-22**] metabolic encephalopathy due to
infection and acute renal failure, with slight improvement after
resolution of urosepsis. Head CT negative for acute process.
Thyroid studies show elevated TSH but this may be c/w sick
euthyroid syndrome.

# Respiratory Distress: Early in her admission, the patient
developed labored breathing after receiving 1 L NS for
hypotension c/w flash pulmonary edema.  Diuresis with furosemide
gtt lead to hypotension; albumin resuscitation lead to repeated
respiratory distress.  On [**2194-1-30**] she was on the floor and had a
witnessed aspiration event and needed 100% Hi Flow mask.  While
in the ICU her O2 was weaned but again aspirated and had
increasing O2 requirements.

# Acute renal failure: Pt noted to have Cr up to 1.7 on
admission from presumed baseline of 1.0, returned to baseline of
0.9. Likely was pre-renal due to dehydration and hypotension due
to sepsis.  Later in her hospital course, the patient was
hypotensive and her creatinine again began to rise thought
secondary to ATN.

# Hypothyroidism:  Initially treated with levothyroxine 12.5 mcg
IV daily (half home dose).  T3 low. TSH elevated.  Resumed home
dose 1/4.

# Anasarca: Pt has diffuse edema and large bilateral pleural
effusions likely third-spacing from malnutrition given low
albumin (2.8 on admission, then 2.2) and poor po intake.
Diuresis has been difficult due to hypotension as detailed
above.  Continue to monitor.

# Urosepsis: Admitted with hypotension due to urosepsis
requiring pressor support. Urine cultures from [**1-9**] were
positive for E.coli, and pt completed treated with vancomycin
and ceftazidime x10 days.  Repeat UCx [**2194-1-19**] grew out yeast,
which was not treated.  Another repeat UCx [**1-22**] final again grew
out yeast.

# Right Hip pain: Pain due to destruction of the right
acetabulum consistent with progressive lymphoma on CT scan.
There is dramatic medial displacement of the right femoral head
secondary to lack of remaining osseous support. Stable
destruction of the right posterior sacroiliac joint and
surrounding right sacral ala and iliac bone. The patient's pain
is being controlled with fentanyl and lidocaine patches.

# Bilateral pleural effusion: R>L, thought most likely due to
agressive hydration in the setting of sepsis and
hypoalbuminemia.  Was difficult to effect a significant diurese
in MICU due to development of hypotension in response to
furosemide. Appears slightly improved on CXR from [**2194-1-17**],
unchanged on [**1-20**] CXR.

# Nodular Sclerosing Hodgkin's Lymphoma: Seen by oncology, no
interventions at this time. Likely with bone marrow infiltration
causing anemia and thrombocytopenia above, as pt with low retic
count and no evidence of hemolysis.  No further treatment per
oncology.

# Coagulopathy: Mild, likely due to nutritional deficiency.
Encourage PO intake and trend LFTs, coags.

[**2194-1-11**] 1:01 PM
 CT CHEST W/O CONTRAST; CT ABDOMEN W/O CONTRAST                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14608**]
 CT PELVIS W/O CONTRAST
 Reason: concern for renal stone, pulmonary process
 Admitting Diagnosis: HYPOTENSION
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  [**Age over 90 **] year old woman with urosepsis, persistently hypotensive despite appropriate
  antibiotic therapy
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  concern for renal stone, pulmonary process
 CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST:
  renal failure
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 STUDY:  CT torso.

 INDICATION:  [**Age over 90 **]-year-old female with urosepsis and persistent hypotensive
 state despite appropriate antibiotic therapy.  Please evaluate for urinary
 tract obstruction/stone or pulmonary process.

 COMPARISON:  [**2193-9-4**].

 TECHNIQUE:  MDCT axially acquired images were obtained from the thoracic inlet
 to the symphysis without intravenous contrast administration.  Multiplanar
 reconstructed images were obtained.

 CT OF THE CHEST WITHOUT INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST:  There are bilateral pleural
 effusions with associated relaxation atelectasis, right greater than left,
 which have increased in size since previous study.  No definite focal
 infiltrate is identified. There is stable atherosclerotic plaque within the
 aorta which is not opacified with contrast. A left internal jugular central
 venous catheter tip terminates in the distal SVC. Stable dense coronary artery
 calcifications are again noted.  No pneumothorax is present. There is a stable
 noncalcified opacity within the left apex (2:11), measuring 8 mm and is
 stable, likely representing scar.  The major airways are patent down to the
 subsegmental level.  Although difficult to evaluate given lack of IV contrast,
 there is no significant increase in axillary or mediastinal adenopathy with
 the largest right axillary lymph node measuring 9 mm.  There is increased
 anasarca and a new simple appearing fluid collection surrounding the right
 pectoralis musculature.

 CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITHOUT IV CONTRAST:  Multiple hypodense lesions within the
 liver are again noted despite lack of IV contrast.  The gallbladder is
 distended without pericholecystic fluid or appreciable wall thickening.  The
 spleen, pancreas, and large and small bowel are unremarkable.  There is a
 stable cyst within the interpolar region of the right kidney.  No
 hydronephrosis, hydroureter or genitourinary calculi present.  The abdominal
 aorta is not focally dilated, although heavily calcified with atherosclerotic
 plaque, including the iliac vessels.  No free air or free fluid within the
 abdomen.

 CT PELVIS WITHOUT CONTRAST:  A Foley catheter is present within the bladder
                                                             (Over)

 [**2194-1-11**] 1:01 PM
 CT CHEST W/O CONTRAST; CT ABDOMEN W/O CONTRAST                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14608**]
 CT PELVIS W/O CONTRAST
 Reason: concern for renal stone, pulmonary process
 Admitting Diagnosis: HYPOTENSION
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
 which is mildly distended with air.  There is an atrophic calcified uterus
 which is not significantly changed in appearance.  A small amount of free
 pelvic fluid.  No free air is identified within the pelvis.

 OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:  There has been dramatic further destruction of the right
 acetabulum with an associated soft tissue mass and medial displacement of the
 femoral head through the bony defect. Soft tissue mass destructing the
 posterior aspect of the right sacroiliac joint and surrounding sacrum and
 ilium is not significantly changed, consistent with known lymphomatous
 destruction. S shaped thoracolumbar scoliosis.

 IMPRESSION:

 1.  Air within the bladder likely secondary to introduction from Foley
 catheter rather than emphysematous cystitis.  No renal stones or
 hydronephrosis.  Stable right renal cyst.

 2.  Increased size of right greater than left pleural effusion and associated
 relaxation atelectasis.

 3.  New small simple appearing fluid collection surronding the right
 pectoralis muscle.

 4.  Increased destruction of the right acetabulum consistent with progressive
 lymphoma.  There is dramatic medial displacement of the right femoral head
 secondary to lack of remaining osseous support. Stable destruction of the
 right posterior sacroiliac joint and surrounding right sacral ala and iliac
 bone.

 5.  Increased anasarca.

 6.  Diffuse aortic atherosclerotic plaque and coronary artery calcification.

PATIENT/TEST INFORMATION:
Indication: Left ventricular function. New afib with RVR.
Height: (in) 63
Weight (lb): 152
BSA (m2): 1.72 m2
BP (mm Hg): 95/46
HR (bpm): 82
Status: Inpatient
Date/Time: [**2194-1-22**] at 14:30
Test: Portable TTE (Complete)
Doppler: Full Doppler and color Doppler
Contrast: None
Technical Quality: Adequate


INTERPRETATION:

Findings:

This study was compared to the prior study of [**2194-1-8**].


LEFT ATRIUM: Mild LA enlargement.

RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: Normal RA size. Normal interatrial septum. No
ASD by 2D or color Doppler.

LEFT VENTRICLE: Normal LV wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global
systolic function (LVEF >55%). No resting LVOT gradient. No VSD.

RIGHT VENTRICLE: Normal RV chamber size and free wall motion.

AORTA: Normal aortic diameter at the sinus level. Mildly dilated ascending
aorta. No 2D or Doppler evidence of distal arch coarctation.

AORTIC VALVE: Mildly thickened aortic valve leaflets (3). No AS. Trace AR.

MITRAL VALVE: Mildly thickened mitral valve leaflets. Trivial MR. LV inflow
pattern c/w impaired relaxation.

TRICUSPID VALVE: Normal tricuspid valve leaflets with trivial TR.
Indeterminate PA systolic pressure.

PULMONIC VALVE/PULMONARY ARTERY: No PS.

PERICARDIUM: No pericardial effusion.

Conclusions:
The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or
color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and
regional/global systolic function are normal (LVEF >55%) There is no
ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion
are normal. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets
(3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace aortic
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Trivial
mitral regurgitation is seen. The left ventricular inflow pattern suggests
impaired relaxation. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be
determined. There is no pericardial effusion.

Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2194-1-8**], no change.

 ****************************************************************************
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  [**Age over 90 **] year old woman with anasarca, hypotension, receiving abx
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Please place IR-guided PICC for abx
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  [**Age over 90 **]-year-old female receiving antibiotics.

 The procedure was explained to the patient.  A preprocedural timeout was
 performed.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 353**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) **] performed the procedure.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **],
 the attending radiologist, was present and supervising.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copy ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, attempts were
 made to advance the guidewire into the SVC.  The guidewire would not advance
 past the axillary vein and therefore a peel-away sheath was placed and a
 venogram performed demonstrating a short, tight stenosis at the right
 axillary/ subclavian vein junction.

 The area of stenosis was traversed under fluoroscopic guidance using a 0.018
 Glidewire.  A repeat venogram demonstrated a small amount of extravasated
 extraluminal contrast; however, the Glidewire was subsequently successfully
 navigated into the SVC.  A single lumen PICC line measuring 43 cm in length
 was then placed through the peel-away sheath with tip positioned in the SVC
 under fluoroscopic guidance. Position of the catheter was confirmed by
 fluoroscopic spot film of the chest. The peel-away sheath and guidewire were
 then removed. The catheter was secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile
 dressing applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Limited venogram demonstrating stenosis at right axillary-subclavian vein
 junction which was traversed with a 0.018 Glidewire.
 2.  Placement of single lumen PICC line via the right brachial venous approach
 with final internal length of 43 cm and tip positioned in the SVC.  The line
 is ready for use.
                                                             (Over)

 [**2194-1-27**] 7:40 AM

 Reason: Please place IR-guided PICC for abx
 Admitting Diagnosis: HYPOTENSION
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 20
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT

Admission Date:  [**2194-1-7**]              Discharge Date:   [**2194-2-2**]


Service: MEDICINE

Allergies:
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs

Attending:[**Last Name (NamePattern4) 290**]
Chief Complaint:
Altered Mental Status and hypotension

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

History of Present Illness:
[**Age over 90 **]F Russian-speaking h/o refractory nodular sclerosing Hodgkins
Lymphoma was brought in by EMS and admitted after her home
health care aide noted she was hypotensive to 88/40 and
confused.

In the ED, T 98.4 (rectal), HR 101, BP 102/53, RR 20, O2Sat 98%
on 3L. Incontinant of guaiac-positive stool.  Treated with 4 L
NS, vanco 1g IV, ceftazadime 1g IV, and flagyl 500mg IV.
Received 0.5 mg ativan and 2mg IV morphine for agitation.

Pt was admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 153**] where she completed a 10-day course of
ceftazadime and vancomycin for urosepsis. A 7-day course of
metronidazole was also completed for empiric treatment of C.
Diff given loose stools in the setting of an elevated WBC count,
although all C. Diff assays were negative. Pt was stabilized and
was transferred to the floor for further care. At the time of
transfer, active issues were poor nutritional status,
thrombocytopenia and anemia.

On the floor, however, pt experienced an episode of new Afib
with RVR to 160s and hypotension to SBP 90-100s, as well as
respiratory distress after she received fluid resuscitation.
There was also a concern for tachy-brady syndrome because she
had pauses up to 4 sec on telemetry; EP curbside, however, felt
digoxin was not recommended.

Pt was therefore readmitted to the MICU.  While in the MICU, she
was started on vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam as she had
(1) sites of possible infection at the erosions under her
breasts and on her right hip, as well as question of PNA, (2)
rising WBC, reaching a high of nearly 17.  MICU course was also
marked by (1) hypotension, which responded to gentle NS boluses;
(2) low UOP believed to be [**2-22**] both hypovolemia and a low
baseline nitrogenous load/obligate urine output; and (3)
recurrent Afib, for which she was transitioned to amiodarone
400mg PO daily, to run for 7 days before titrating downward.

Past Medical History:
# Nodular sclerosing Hodgkins Lymphoma ([**3-/2188**])
--Presentation: Inguinal lymphadenopathy, treated with local
radiotherapy initially with good results.
--CT [**8-23**]: Progression, treated with Cytoxan, Velban and
Prednisone with a good response
--Eroding mass at sacrum, treated with radiation therapy
--[**3-/2191**]: Severe hypoxemia, somnolence, and generalized edema,
with anasarca responsive to diuresis and oxygen supplements, and
discharged on constant oxygen
--[**3-/2191**]: CVVP trial, stopped in [**10-28**] because of low blood
counts
--Low-dose modified regimen: Chlorambucil 4mg daily for days
[**1-27**], Procarbazine 50mg daily for days [**1-27**], Velban 10 mg IV on
day 1 only, Neulasta 6mg on day 8.
--[**9-/2192**]: Chemotherapy discontinued given poor response
--[**1-/2193**]: L sided chest pain with lytic lesions in the thoracic
vertebrae; received radiation therapy to T6-T8 including the
right 7th rib
--CT [**8-/2193**]: Interval decrease in vertebral lesions.

# Lower extremity cellulitis
# GERD

# Constipation

Lives at home with health care aide.  Son [**Name (NI) **] very involved in
her care.  Three children. No tobacco, alcohol, and illicit drug
use.

Noncontributory

[**1-10**].  Echo.
The left atrium is normal in size. No atrial septal defect is
seen by 2D or color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thicknesses
are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Overall
left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). Right

is no aortic valve stenosis. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen.
